title: Keith Miller reviews PizzaExpress, London W1: 'a sacrament of togetherness'
text:
This review was first published in January, 2019, and has been republished.

The restaurateur Peter Boizot, who died on Dec 5, was remembered kindly by friends and obituarists. Boizot, who took on the lease of a struggling Soho joint called PizzaExpress in 1965, was a true pathfinder, twigging how this humble Neapolitan foodstuff could be made the basis of a contemporary, cosmopolitan and even mildly swinging dining experience, a groovy cavalcade of primary colours, Paolozzi murals and – God help us – live jazz.

As his empire grew, he kept things simple and at least vaguely authentic (no ham and pineapple), establishing the first – though by no means last – “good chain”, somewhere you could take the kids or go à deux after a subtitled film, somewhere (once it had outspread the capital) that might catch your eye if you were in an unfamiliar town, looking for lunch the day after a wedding, say.

But during the past decade and more, a tsunami of innovation – be it rival and more aggressively authentocratic pizzerias such as Franco Manca, or the broader phenomenon of sharp, focused “casual dining” chains, your Wahacas and Busaba Eathais – have left the PE formula looking a little soggy (though Boizot stepped back from the business by this time). This seemed like a good moment to raise a glass of house red to Boizot’s memory, and maybe just gently take stock of his legacy.
